name: NewYorker
text: “I often have trouble making sense of an experience until I’ve laboriously written it down, or turned it into fiction.” An interview with Paul Theroux. https://t.co/TjgDBAnobR

name: NewYorker
text: In an except drawn from “The Dead Are Arising: The Life of Malcolm X,” Les Payne details the assassination of Malcolm X and the government’s botched investigation of his murder. https://t.co/rgKEe1QkT0

name: NewYorker
text: Our TV critics offer 40 recommendations for home viewing, from the “The Brady Bunch” to “Schitt’s Creek.” https://t.co/1nvlFc0T4d

name: NewYorker
text: Mandy Patinkin discusses his four-decade career, the importance of walking towards fear, and becoming a quarantine social-media star. https://t.co/tzFNeCapov

name: NewYorker
text: “Every Belarusian is overcoming their fears right now,” the leader of democratic Belarus said. “Two months ago, I couldn’t bring myself to say words like ‘dictator’ or ‘usurper’ about Lukashenka. The more he cracks down, the easier it gets.” https://t.co/fmJVeFQJvn

name: NewYorker
text: “Right from the beginning, I’ve always gone to stories when I feel that I can tell them in a special way, that they’re mine, that they won’t let me go.” An interview with the filmmaker @MiraPagliNair. https://t.co/qcfyrtrx6g

name: NewYorker
text:
Over a lifetime, we will lose some 200,000 items apiece, plus money, relationships, elections, loved ones.

text: A scene from Oliver Hirschbiegel’s 2004 film “Downfall,” of Hitler’s final days, has spawned a thousand YouTube parodies. But it is based, in part, on problematic sources. https://t.co/Gvk8VHjARe

name: NewYorker
text: Nearly every aspect of our pandemic response has become politicized, @DhruvKhullar writes. Our greatest challenge is not the virus but ourselves. https://t.co/u6k9Jss1J1

name: NewYorker
text:
The New York Botanical Garden is home to some hundred thousand species of trees, ferns, shrubs, wildflowers, and grasses, all indigenous to the Northeast.
https://t.co/SnBhLTuype

name: NewYorker
text: David Fincher’s new film, “Mank,” is an attempt to define the nature of Herman Mankiewicz’s contribution to “Citizen Kane,” and to the history of cinema—and to dramatize his battle to get credit for it. https://t.co/qa7BNOf4Eo

name: NewYorker
text: Crowns have been worn by rulers and divinities of both sexes since prehistoric times. https://t.co/pRhuO2C9Ls

name: NewYorker
text:
David Fincher’s "Mank" is an astutely probing and pain-filled work of speculative historical psychology, @tnyfrontrow writes—and a vision of Hollywood politics that shines a spotlight on current events.
https://t.co/EQmr5brV44

name: NewYorker
text: Actors always allow us to imagine lives beyond our own; this year, they were our avatars, roaming free while we sat and watched and waited. https://t.co/CkJV5t8uUv

name: NewYorker
text:

text: For the cover of this week’s issue, David Hockney offers the traditional comfort of a hearth, illustrated on an iPad. https://t.co/K9b1hOkugS

name: NewYorker
text: RT @dlcantwell: “It’s my music, too.” R.I.P. Charley Pride, one of the greatest country acts, and one of the greatest popular artists, we’ll ever be so lucky to know. I tried to get down a bit of why he matters (present tense) in this essay from last year. #charleypride  https://t.co/O5fbTohUA0

name: NewYorker
text: As a child, the animator Tomm Moore squirrelled away acetate sheets that his father, an engineer, brought home from work, and used them to paint cels with superheroes. Now the studio he co-founded produces movies using essentially the same techniques. https://t.co/9UYvpgt7Vt

name: NewYorker
text: The inventor of windup plastic teeth and more than 800 other toys is still tinkering at his home in a retirement community. A new documentary demonstrates the lingering joy that he takes in the precise work of inventing. Watch here. https://t.co/lngQVLsi77

name: NewYorker
text: Taylor Swift’s “evermore” is a lush, tender, and beautiful album, @amandapetrusich writes—steadier if less varied than “folklore,” and infused with backward-looking wisdom. https://t.co/USbhtoDZrd

name: NewYorker
text: Where do contributions to Donald Trump’s campaign Web site—still active today, and aggressively soliciting donations—actually go? https://t.co/hLCipYmiEX

name: NewYorker
text: RT @gordoncorera: Le Carre was always discreet about his MI6 years. “it's a matter of pride to me that nobody who knows the reality has so far accused me of revealing it’” he once told me. This piece he wrote though comes closest and has some sharp observations on spies https://t.co/0JQPmqADGx

name: NewYorker
text: For professors, particularly those in the social sciences, COVID-19 has provided real-time studies on which to center syllabi. https://t.co/IxSaA5G232

name: NewYorker
text: RT @mrkocnnll: I wrote about the Irish animation studio Cartoon Saloon for @NewYorker. It was very cool to spend the lockdown summer talking to the people who have made this amazing thing in Kilkenny, my own home town, and to write about it for the magazine https://t.co/kOGoZ0MvsY

name: NewYorker
text: Some time after “A Perfect Spy” came out, in 1986, Philip Roth remarked that it was “the best English novel since the war.” https://t.co/Xfid8lINyp

name: NewYorker
text: In this week’s issue of The New Yorker, @bentaub91 writes about the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, whose reporting exposed corruption within Malta’s governing class—and whose sons led a campaign for the truth that eventually brought down the government. https://t.co/4J3eDCBSP4

name: NewYorker
text: .@nicolatwilley writes about the acceleration of research into phages—viruses that infect only bacteria—amid an ever-growing threat of antibiotic-resistant pathogens. https://t.co/QLMlB6pfwf

name: NewYorker
text: Democrats cannot achieve anything without bipartisan dealmaking, Abigail Spanberger says—however unwelcome it may be to progressives. Listen to her discussion with David Remnick on a new episode of our Politics and More podcast. https://t.co/KPhGNM8IBZ
